question: Define serial and parallel transmission. State one advantage of serial transmission over parallel.
mark_scheme: Serial = one bit at a time down a single channel
Parallel = multiple bits sent simultaneously across multiple channels
Serial better over long distances as no signal skew

question: Explain the difference between synchronous and asynchronous data transmission.
mark_scheme: Synchronous uses a shared clock signal to synchronise sender and receiver
Asynchronous relies on start/stop bits to mark beginning/end of transmission

question: Define baud rate, bit rate, bandwidth, latency, and protocol.
mark_scheme: Baud rate = signal changes per second
Bit rate = bits per second transmitted
Bandwidth = maximum data transfer capacity
Latency = delay in transmission
Protocol = set of rules governing communication

question: Explain the purpose of start and stop bits in asynchronous communication.
mark_scheme: Start bit tells receiver when data begins
Stop bit signals end of data
Helps synchronise without clock signal

question: Discuss how both bandwidth and latency affect the user experience when streaming live video.
mark_scheme: Bandwidth determines video resolution/quality possible
High bandwidth allows HD or 4K
Latency affects responsiveness and delay between live event and playback
High latency causes lag/buffering
Even high bandwidth cannot compensate for poor latency
Optimal streaming needs high bandwidth + low latency

question: Describe the difference between a physical star topology and a logical bus topology.
mark_scheme: Physical star = devices connect to central hub/switch
Logical bus = devices share one communication channel
A star network can act logically as a bus if bus protocol used

question: Explain the difference between peer-to-peer and client-server networking, giving one advantage of each.
mark_scheme: Peer-to-peer: devices share resources equally
Client-server: central server provides services to clients
Peer-to-peer advantage: simple, low-cost setup
Client-server advantage: centralised management/security

question: Explain the role of a wireless access point (WAP) in WiFi networking.
mark_scheme: WAP connects wireless devices to wired LAN
Acts as bridge between wireless clients and network infrastructure

question: Describe two methods used to secure a wireless network.
mark_scheme: WPA2 encryption protects transmitted data
Disabling SSID broadcast makes network less visible
MAC address whitelisting restricts access to approved devices

question: Explain how CSMA/CA with RTS/CTS helps to reduce collisions in wireless networks.
mark_scheme: Carrier Sense: device checks channel is clear before sending
Collision Avoidance: waits random back-off time
RTS: sender requests permission to transmit
CTS: receiver confirms channel is clear
This reduces hidden node collisions

question: Define what is meant by a packet in Internet communication and list three fields typically found in its header.
mark_scheme: Packet = unit of data sent across a network
Header fields: source IP, destination IP, sequence number, error-checking code (checksum)
May also include protocol identifier

question: Explain the purpose of DNS in Internet communication.
mark_scheme: DNS translates human-readable domain names into IP addresses
Allows users to access websites without remembering numeric addresses

question: Discuss one security threat faced by Internet users and explain how it can be mitigated.
mark_scheme: Threat example: phishing
Mitigation: user education, spam filters
Other answers: malware → antivirus, firewalls; DoS → filtering, load balancing

question: Analyse the importance of encryption in securing online banking transactions.
mark_scheme: Encryption protects confidentiality of data
Prevents interception of sensitive information
Ensures integrity and prevents tampering
SSL/TLS protocols used
Relies on public key cryptography and certificates
Weakness if certificates compromised or outdated

question: Evaluate the effectiveness of measures against Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks.
mark_scheme: Rate limiting restricts request floods
Firewalls block malicious traffic
Content delivery networks (CDNs) absorb excess load
Blackholing drops all traffic to attacked server
Intrusion detection systems monitor abnormal activity
Each measure has limitations
Layered defence is most effective

question: List the four layers of the TCP/IP stack in order. Give one example protocol from each layer.
mark_scheme: Application: HTTP/SMTP/FTP
Transport: TCP/UDP
Internet: IP
Link: Ethernet/WiFi

question: Explain the main difference between IPv4 and IPv6 addressing and state one reason why IPv6 was introduced.
mark_scheme: IPv4 uses 32-bit addresses (~4.3 billion)
IPv6 uses 128-bit addresses (virtually unlimited)
IPv6 introduced due to IPv4 exhaustion

question: Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of using Network Address Translation (NAT).
mark_scheme: Advantages: conserves IPv4 addresses, hides internal addresses (security), allows multiple devices behind one public IP
Disadvantages: breaks true end-to-end connectivity, complicates peer-to-peer applications and VoIP

question: Compare thin-client and thick-client computing and suggest where each would be more appropriate.
mark_scheme: Thin client: processing done on server
Thick client: processing done locally
Thin = cheaper hardware, easy maintenance, requires strong network
Thick = more expensive, more powerful, can work offline
Thin good for large organisations
Thick good for mobile/power users

question: Evaluate the importance of REST and JSON compared to SOAP and XML in modern web applications.
mark_scheme: REST is lightweight, stateless, scalable
JSON is easier and faster to parse than XML
SOAP/XML is verbose and complex
REST/JSON widely adopted for APIs
Cross-platform compatibility
Performance advantages
SOAP/XML still used in enterprise for strict standards
Evaluation: REST/JSON dominant but SOAP/XML remains relevant
